channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Appeals Court Frees Justice Dept. to Use Sensitive Files Seized From Trump
item.description: A federal judge had temporarily barred the department from using the records marked as classified in its inquiry into whether the former president illegally retained national defense documents.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.media:description: A supporter of former President Donald J. Trump driving through West Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: Trump Is Sued for Fraud By New York State A.G. Letitia James
item.description: The New York attorney general, Letitia James, is seeking to bar the Trump family from ever operating in the state again.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich, William K. Rashbaum and Ben Protess
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Although the lawsuit against Donald J. Trump cannot include criminal charges, the former president could face substantial financial penalties.

item.title: Vladimir Putin When Cornered Is More Dangerous Than Ever
item.description: In a major speech, he recast the war in Ukraine and made clear it could spread.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Calling up 300,000 reservists, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia tacitly acknowledged both Russia’s struggles and the existence of a unified Ukraine.

item.title: Biden Paints Russia as a Threat to the World in U.N. Speech
item.description: President Biden portrayed Russia as the chief threat to global peace and renewed warnings that “a nuclear war cannot be won.”
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley, David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: President Biden told the United Nations General Assembly in New York on Wednesday that the West “will stand in solidarity against Russia’s aggression.”

item.title: Putin Raises Stakes in the War, With Direct Challenge to the West
item.description: The Russian leader announced a call-up of troops and hinted at using nuclear weapons, accusing the West of trying to “destroy our country” and vowing that Russia would defend itself.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A recruitment poster for the Russian military in Saint Petersburg this week.

item.title: Virginia Thomas Agrees to Interview With Jan. 6 Panel
item.description: The committee has sought for months to interview Ms. Thomas, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas, about her involvement in efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:description: Virginia Thomas with her husband, Justice Clarence Thomas. Her cooperation comes as the Jan. 6 committee is entering its final months of work.

item.title: House Passes Overhaul of Electoral Count, Moving to Avert Another Jan. 6 Crisis
item.description: The legislation, opposed by most Republicans, is a bid to update the law that former President Donald J. Trump tried to exploit on Jan. 6, 2021, to invalidate his defeat.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence and Speaker Nancy Pelosi presiding over the counting of Electoral College votes in the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The legislation would define the vice president’s role as strictly ministerial.

item.title: The Fed Intensifies Its Battle Against Inflation
item.description: Federal Reserve officials made another large rate increase and signaled more to come, pledging to quash inflation despite expected pain.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek

item.title: What Fed Rate Increases Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
item.description: Savers will benefit and borrowers can expect to pay more on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard

item.title: How ‘Lord of the Rings’ Inspires Italy’s Giorgia Meloni
item.description: Giorgia Meloni, the nationalist politician who is the front-runner to become prime minister, sees “The Lord of the Rings” as not just a series of novels, but also a sacred text.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: As a youth activist, Giorgia Meloni revered “The Lord of the Rings” and other works by the British writer J.R.R. Tolkien.

item.title: Drenched by Hurricane Fiona, Puerto Ricans Band Together
item.description: Neighbors are moving ruined appliances and, with brooms and shovels, wiping away the mud that coats their homes. They learned from Hurricane Maria not to wait for official help.
item.dc:creator: Laura N. Pérez Sánchez
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: With the help of her family, María Cortés Dávila cleaned her home after Hurricane Fiona dumped rain on Toa Baja, P.R. Some parts of the island received 30 inches.

item.title: In New Film, Former Employee Says Mario Batali Sexually Assaulted Her
item.description: A woman who worked for the chef comes forward with her account of a night at the Spotted Pig in Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: Julia Moskin and Kim Severson
item.category: Batali: The Fall of a Superstar Chef (Movie)
item.media:description: It took five years after the #MeToo movement began for Eva DeVirgilis, who worked for Mario Batali, to go public with her account.

item.title: See Images of Neptune Come Into Focus With Webb Telescope
item.description: New images from the space-based observatory offer a novel view of the planet in infrared.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan O’Callaghan
item.media:description: Neptune with its rings and several of its moons clearly visible, as captured by the James Webb Space Telescope’s Near Infrared Camera.

item.title: ‘Don’t Worry Darling’ Review: Burning Down the Dollhouse
item.description: Florence Pugh plays a seemingly happy housewife whose world starts to crack apart in Olivia Wilde’s wobbly feminist gothic.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Russia’s Putin Is in Trouble
item.description: The ground beneath his feet has started to shift.
item.dc:creator: Marlene Laruelle

item.title: Inside the Completely Legal G.O.P. Plot to Destroy American Democracy
item.description: Imagine a legal January 6. It’s bureaucratic, boring, invisible, and it might actually succeed.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Harris and Michelle Cottle

item.title: Herschel Walker Says He’s ‘Not That Smart.’ I Believe Him.
item.description: Walker is attempting to lower the bar of the upcoming debate so low so that anyone, even Walker, can clear it.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: The Midlife Crisis Is Very Real and Nothing to Be Laughed At
item.description: It may be a result of our affluent world. Or it may be biological.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images, via Getty Images

item.title: Three Paths Toward an Endgame for Putin’s War
item.description: But here are three possibilities.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man painting over the Russian flag in a recently recaptured Ukrainian village.

item.title: Democrats Are Starting to Feel Hopeful About the Midterms. Should They?
item.description: Summer fears of an electoral wipeout have given way to cautious optimism as Democrats enjoy a changed political environment.
item.dc:creator: Spencer Bokat-Lindell
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by Olivier Douliery, Anna Moneymaker and Andrii Shyp, via Getty Images

item.title: Are There Better Places to Put Large Solar Farms Than These Forests?
item.description: For the great promise of renewable energy to be realized, states like Virginia must create an environment where solar, nature and people can peaceably coexist.
item.dc:creator: Gabriel Popkin
item.media:credit: Melissa Lyttle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Twitty’s Creek Solar, a 134-acre, 15-megawatt installation along Highway 59, is the first solar project operating in Charlotte County, Va.

item.title: ‘We Can’t Let the Kids Go Outdoors’: Our New Reality on the West Coast
item.description: For children there, it isn’t a question of what you want to do outside; it’s whether it is even safe to leave the house.
item.dc:creator: Emma Pattee

item.title: Welcome to Wrexham: It’s the Future
item.description: Rob McElhenney and Ryan Reynolds seem sincere about their investment, emotionally and financially, in a Welsh soccer team. But they are not mere observers in its story.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: Modern Love Podcast: How to Feel Yourself
item.description: At 83, and legally blind, a woman needs help with one of her favorite pastimes: visiting the sex shop.

item.title: For Churches, Abortion Politics Is a Double-Edged Sword
item.description: Ireland and Poland went in entirely opposite directions on abortion. Why?
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Supporters celebrate at Dublin Castle after a constitutional amendment legalizing abortion passed in 2018.

item.title: What Did You Wear to That Wedding?
item.description: Were you invited to a wedding with a nontraditional dress code (think: desert chic or coastal glam)? We want to see what you wore.
item.dc:creator: Emma Grillo
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times

item.title: In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge Trials Come to an End
item.description: The last surviving leader of the regime that killed 1.7 million Cambodians lost his appeal on Thursday. Some victims think the long, expensive tribunal was a hollow exercise.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nhet Sok Heng/Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Khieu Samphan, 91, the last surviving Khmer Rouge leader, during his hearing at the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia in Phnom Penh on Thursday.

item.title: Senate Ratifies Kigali Amendment, the Global Pact to Curb Hydrofluorocarbons
item.description: In a bipartisan vote, lawmakers voted to join an international agreement to phase out the hydrofluorocarbons commonly found in refrigerators and air-conditioners.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
item.category: Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Air-conditioners in New Delhi in April. The Kigali Amendment of 2016 aims to sharply reduce the use of planet-warming refrigerants known as hydrofluorocarbons.

item.title: Pentagon Admits Lack of Oversight to Stop Junior R.O.T.C. Sexual Abuse
item.description: Facing questions from senators about repeated cases of abuse in J.R.O.T.C. programs, military leaders said they wanted to increase scrutiny of the instructors.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Mike Baker
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Some cadets and public school administrators say J.R.O.T.C. is a way to impart discipline and life skills, while the military receives the recruiting benefit of introducing teenagers to the armed forces.

item.title: Protests in Iran Intensify Over the Death of Mahsa Amini in Custody
item.description: Unrest has spread to dozens of cities, with at least seven people killed, according to witnesses, rights groups and video posted on social media.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Protesters in Tehran on Thursday. Unrest erupted last weekend after Mahsa Amini died in police custody following an arrest under the law on head scarves.

item.title: Speeding Up Your Daily Walk Could Have Big Benefits
item.description: In the largest study to incorporate activity tracker data, picking up the pace paid dividends for long-term health.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times

item.title: Cardio and Strength Training May Help You Live Longer, Study Says
item.description: A consensus is building among experts that both strength training and cardio‌ are important for longevity.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank

item.title: Breaking Up With Peloton
item.description: The stationary bike’s convenience made it a pandemic winner, but some former fans are done working out at home.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns

item.title: How Health Care Workers Got Me Through the Pandemic
item.description: From home aides to doctors, people in health care fields offered more than just medical advice for people getting through the pandemic. They offered comfort.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Needelman
item.media:credit: Frances F. Denny for The New York Times
item.media:description: Devon Jacoby, seated left on the bench, surrounded by members of the staff of Saint Catherine Center for Special Needs in Fairfield, Conn. “You don’t work with people like my daughter and do it well because it’s a job,” said Doug Jacoby, her father. “You do it because it’s a calling.”

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
